title: Steele v. Steele
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        David E. Steele, Respondent,
        v.
        Clara M. Steele, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
The Hon. Roger E. Henderson, Family Court
Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-590
Heard September 18, 2008 â€“ Filed October
16, 2008
AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        G. Robin Alley, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Philip E. Wright, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Following separate hearings on liability and damages,
  the family court held Clara M. Steele (Wife) in contempt for killing the plants surrounding the marital
  home following the partiesâ€™ divorce.Â  Wife now appeals the family courtâ€™s order requiring her to pay David E. Steele (Husband) $45,759.90 in
  damages and an additional $1,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.Â  Â Â 
FACTS
Husband and Wife were divorced on April 3, 2003.Â  They later
  entered into a property settlement agreement in which Husband agreed pay Wife
  $5,000 for moving expenses, $45,000 by May 15, 2003, and an additional $40,000
  by April 1, 2007.Â  Wife agreed to vacate the marital home by April 15, 2003.Â  Under
  this settlement agreement, each party promised not to â€œdestroy or damage any
  real or personal property of the other party.â€Â  The family court adopted and
  incorporated this agreement into its order dated March 28, 2003, concerning
  property division.Â  Wife held exclusive physical possession of the marital home
  until she vacated the home on April 15, 2003.Â  Shortly after Husband moved into
  the home on April 16, 2003, he observed signs of damage or disease in the
  plants and trees near the house.[1]Â 
  Within thirteen days, many of the plants around the house were dead or dying.Â  Â Â 
Husband brought a contempt action against Wife, alleging she had
  damaged and destroyed plants, shrubs, and trees around the marital home, and
  requesting the family court permit him to withhold the $45,000 payment until
  the contempt action had been heard.Â  The family court granted his request to
  withhold payment and heard the contempt action on June 9, 2003.Â  Husband
  testified he believed Wife had applied an unknown biological agent to the
  soil.Â  To test this theory, Husband planted new plants in the contaminated soil
  to see if they would survive.Â  The new plants died almost immediately.Â  Husband
  also engaged other landscapers to help him document the damage and estimate the
  cost of repair. Â Â Â Â 
After a hearing, the family court held Wife in contempt, awarded
  Husband $1,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees incurred in prosecuting the contempt action,
  and ordered Husband to engage the services of a licensed contractor to return
  the property as close as possible to its previous condition.Â  Furthermore, the
  family court ordered Wife to bear the cost of removing any contaminated soil
  and replacing all the plants that were destroyed.Â  Both the cost of restoring
  the property and the attorneyâ€™s fees were to be deducted from the $45,000
  Husband owed Wife.Â  Â Â 
Wife subsequently moved for reconsideration.Â  The family court amended
  the damages provision of the contempt order to require each party to obtain an
  estimate for removing the soil and replacing the plants and to attempt to come
  to an agreement on the cost of restoring the property.[2]Â  Both parties obtained estimates, but
  they were unable to agree upon cost. 
On February 26, 2007, the family court heard testimony to determine
  the measure of damages.Â  Wife presented an estimate of approximately $6,000,
  which reflected only the cost of planting new plants and trees.Â  Husband
  presented two estimates and an expert.Â  One estimate, for $18,505, covered
  replacing only the plants.Â  The other estimate, for approximately $78,000,
  reflected the costs of excavating, removing, disposing of, and replacing the
  contaminated soil; removing the dead plants and trees; and installing mature
  plants and trees the approximate sizes of those that died.Â  Husband also sought
  an additional $1,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees incurred since the first hearing.Â  The
  family court awarded Husband $45,759.90 in damages and the additional $1,500 in
  attorneyâ€™s fees, all to be deducted from the monies Husband owed Wife.Â  This
  appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Measure of
  Damages
Wife
  asserts the family court erred in using the cost of restoring the land as close
  as possible to its original condition to determine the amount of damages, when
  that cost was disproportionate to the diminution in value of the land.Â  We
  disagree.
In
  appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find
  the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  Ex Parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649,
  652 (2006).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require the
  appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten v.
    Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).Â  Neither is the
  appellate court required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and
  heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and
  assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360
  S.C. 375, 380, 602 S.E.2d 32, 34 (2004).Â  â€œ[B]ecause the family court is
  in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its
  findings should be given broad discretion.â€Â  Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206,
  211-12, 634 S.E.2d 51, 54 (Ct. App. 2006).
Generally,
  a court may measure damages to property by determining the cost of restoring
  damaged or destroyed trees, shrubs, and other vegetation.Â  Restatement (Second)
  of Torts Â§ 929(1)(a) (1979).Â  If the restoration cost is disproportionate to
  the diminution in value of the land, the proper measure of damages is the lost
  value of the land, unless the owner has a personal reason for restoration.Â  Id. at cmt. b.Â  Â 
Our
  supreme court has found the Restatementâ€™s reasoning persuasive in measuring
  damages when noncommercial trees, shrubs, and related vegetation have been
  destroyed:Â  

	We
  adopt the following as the measure of damages: Â The general measure of damages
  for damaged/destroyed noncommercial trees, shrubs, and related vegetation is
  the difference in the value of the entire parcel of land-damaged and undamaged
  portions-immediately before and after the loss. Â When the property is
  restorable to its former condition at a cost less than the diminution in value,
  then the cost of restoration that has been or may be reasonably incurred or the
  diminution in value may be the proper measure of damages. Â When
    the cost of restoration exceeds the diminution in value, then the greater cost
    of restoration will be allowed when the landowner has a personal reason
    relating to the land for restoring the land to its original condition and when
    the cost of restoration is reasonable in relation to the damage inflicted.Â 
    However, the landowner may not recover restoration costs which exceed the
    market value of the entire parcel prior to the loss. Â Further, the jury may
  consider factors in determining the diminution in value, including but not
  limited to: the types and sizes of the damaged or destroyed trees and shrubs,
  the purpose for which the destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs were grown or
  maintained, the reasonable and practicable replacement costs, and the use of
  the particular land, including any aesthetic value to the landowners of such
  trees and shrubs. 

Vaught v. A.O. Hardee
  & Sons, Inc., 366 S.C. 475, 484, 623
  S.E.2d 373, 377-78 (2005) (emphasis added) (internal cites omitted).Â  
Husband,
  a landscaper by trade, testified he and Wife had planted numerous plants around
  the marital home in an effort â€œto make it look nice.â€Â  Some of the trees around
  the home were mature, providing shade and measuring twelve inches in diameter
  when they were killed.Â  Husband testified he â€œdid all the major plantingâ€
  because Wifeâ€™s medical conditions prevented her from doing it.Â  The family
  court observed Wifeâ€™s sister and cousin testified at trial Wife stated if
  Husband received the house in the divorce, she would kill these landscaping
  improvements so Husband and his girlfriend â€œwould not be able to enjoy the
  house.â€Â  The family court found these witnesses more credible than Wifeâ€™s
  witnesses, who testified they had not heard these statements and Wife would not
  have confided in Husbandâ€™s witnesses.Â  
We
  agree with the family court the destruction of these plants and trees was
  â€œvicious, vindictive, and designed to deny [Husband] and his intended wife
  quiet enjoyment of the house.â€Â  Furthermore, Husbandâ€™s desire to restore the
  landscaping he personally labored to create around his home constitutes â€œa personal
  reason relating to the land for restoring the land to its original condition.â€Â  See Vaught, 366 S.C. at 484, 623 S.E.2d at 378.Â  Husband
  testified the house and surrounding two acres where the landscaping was located
  were worth approximately $160,000.Â  Under Vaught, Husband is entitled to
  a reasonable damages award of less than $160,000.Â  The family courtâ€™s award of
  $45,759.90 does not exceed this amount and reflects the reasonable cost of
  returning the land to its pre-injury condition.Â  Therefore, the family court
  did not err in awarding Husband damages based on the cost of restoring the lost
  plants and trees.Â  
II.  Speculative
  Damages
Wife asserts the
  family court erred in awarding damages
  that were speculative in nature.Â  We disagree.Â  

	The
  trial court is vested with considerable discretion over the amount of a damages
  award, and our review of the amount of damages is limited to the correction of
  errors of law. Â In reviewing a damages award, we do not weigh the evidence, but
  determine if any evidence supports the award.

Vortex Sports &
  Entertainment, Inc. v. Ware, 378 S.C.
  197, 208, 662 S.E.2d 444, 450 (Ct. App. 2008).Â  
At the family
  courtâ€™s behest, both Husband and Wife obtained professional estimates of the
  cost to repair the landscaping damage.Â  Because each party interpreted the degree of damage to its own
  advantage, the estimated repair costs differed considerably.Â  Wife contemplated
  replacing only the plants and presented an estimate of approximately $6,000.Â 
  Conversely, Husband sought to return the landscaped area to its pre-injury
  state and presented both expert testimony and two estimates.Â  His expertâ€™s
  estimate, which included removing, disposing of, and replacing the contaminated
  soil, was approximately $78,000.[3]Â 
  His written estimate for plant replacement, only, totaled $18,505.Â  The family
  court ultimately awarded Husband $45,759.90 in damages, which is well within
  the range of costs established by the written and testimonial evidence.Â 
  Furthermore, the family court itemized the components of this award in its
  final order, and the estimates and testimony support the individual amounts.Â 
  Because the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s award of damages, the award is
  not based upon speculative evidence, and the family court did not abuse its
  discretion.Â Â Â Â Â  
III.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife
  asserts the family court erred in awarding Husband an additional $1,500 in
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.Â  
The
  family court has jurisdiction to award reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees where a claim
  for attorneyâ€™s fees is well-founded.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-3-120 through -140,
  Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2007).Â  In a family court matter, â€œ[t]he award of
  attorneyâ€™s fees . . . will only be disturbed upon a showing of abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648
  (2006).Â  â€œA decision lacking a discernible reason is arbitrary and constitutes
  an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 304, 372
  S.E.2d 107, 115 (Ct. App. 1988).Â 
Wife
  asserts the family court erred solely because it had already awarded Husband
  $1,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and any further award is barred by the doctrine of
  res judicata.Â  A party asserting res judicata must show: â€œ(1) identity of the
  parties; (2) identity of the subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue
  on the merits in the former suit by a court of competent jurisdiction.â€Â  Duckett
    v. Goforth, 374 S.C. 446, 465, 649 S.E.2d 72, 82 (Ct App. 2007) (emphasis omitted).Â 
  Although the parties to this award of attorneyâ€™s fees are the same, the subject
  matter is not.Â  On June 16, 2003, the family court awarded Husband $1,000 in
  attorneyâ€™s fees incurred in his action to determine Wifeâ€™s liability for the
  loss of the plants and trees.Â  The attorneyâ€™s fees now at issue were awarded on
  March 31, 2007, nearly four years later.Â  By this time, Husband had incurred
  attorneyâ€™s fees for the damages portion of his action, which included a lengthy
  hearing at which Husbandâ€™s counsel examined or cross-examined Husband, Wife, an
  expert, and a witness.Â  Because the family courtâ€™s second award of attorneyâ€™s
  fees occurred after Husband incurred additional expense to prosecute a
  different aspect of his claim, res judicata does not apply.Â  Therefore, no
  double recovery occurred, and the family court did not abuse its discretion in
  awarding Husband an additional $1,500 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
CONCLUSION
As
  to the issue of the proper measure of damages, we find the years of care and
  personal labor Husband invested in the landscaping surrounding the marital home
  constitute a personal reason for restoring the landscaping to its pre-injury
  condition.Â  We further find the amount of damages ordered by the family court
  was reasonable and did not exceed the value of the land.Â  Therefore, the family
  court did not err in measuring damages using the actual cost of restoration
  rather than the diminution in overall value of the land.[4]Â 
  Accordingly, we affirm the order of the family court on this issue.Â  
As
  to the issue of speculative damages, we find the professional estimates
  submitted into evidence by the parties support the family courtâ€™s determination
  of damages.Â  The damages are not speculative.Â  Therefore, we affirm the order
  of the family court on this issue.Â  
Finally,
  as to the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees, we find the doctrine of res judicata does
  not bar a supplemental award of attorneyâ€™s fees because the supplemental award
  was based on additional work completed and additional fees incurred after the
  initial award.Â  Consequently, we affirm the order of the family court on this
  issue.Â  
Accordingly,
  the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.Â  
HUFF and
  GEATHERS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] Husband
  was a landscaper with a degree in horticulture and a South Carolina pesticide
license.Â  Wife was a master gardener with expertise in horticulture.
[2] Wife appealed from this order, and this court
  affirmed the family courtâ€™s determination of liability but remanded for
  determination of damages. Â See Steele v. Steele, 2004-UP-578
(Nov. 17, 2004).Â  
[3] This written estimate does not appear in the record,
but his expert testified in support of it.Â  
[4] There is no evidence of the difference in value of
the land before and after the injury to it.Â

title: Mungin v. REA Construction
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE, IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Jimmy Mungin,
      Jr., Claimant, Appellant,
				v.
				REA Construction
      Company, Employer, and Zurich-American Insurance Group, Carrier, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Jasper County
Â Perry M. Buckner, III, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-591
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				R. Thayer Rivers, Jr., of Ridgeland, for Appellant.
				Paul Linwood Hendrix, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this
  workersâ€™ compensation case, Jimmy Mungin appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order
  affirming the decision of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Commission.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities.
1.  As
  to whether the Appellate Panel erred in holding Mungin was not entitled to
  disability benefits: Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2007) (providing an appellate court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment
  of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact
  and may reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the findings,
  inferences, conclusions, or decisions are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the
  reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole recordâ€); Grant v.
    Grant Textiles, 372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007) (holding an
  appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s
  decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled
  by some error of law); McCraw v. Mary Black Hosp., 350 S.C. 229, 235,
  565 S.E.2d 286, 289 (2002) (â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere
  scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, considering the record as a whole,
  would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the agency reached.â€); Sharpe
    v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999)
  (holding the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by
  substantial evidence in the record and the possibility of drawing two
  inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative
  agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by substantial evidence).
2.  As
  to whether the Appellate Panel erred in awarding permanent partial disability
  benefits based on a five percent impairment rating: Grant v. Grant Textiles,
  372 S.C. 196, 201, 641 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2007) (holding an appellate courtâ€™s
  review is limited to deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is
  unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law).
3.  As
  to whether the Appellate Panel erred in denying Munginâ€™s request for
  reimbursement of unauthorized medical costs: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (Supp.
  2007) (establishing the rights of the employer and the employee with regard to
  payment for medical treatment, and ultimately affording much discretion to the Appellate
  Panel); Turner v. S.C. Dept. of Health and Envtl. Control, 377 S.C. 540,
  546, 661 S.E.2d 118, 121 (Ct. App. 2008) (holding Â§ 42-15-60 does not give
  claimants a unilateral right to select their treating physician).
AFFIRMED.Â  Â Â 

HEARN,
  C.J., and HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO

  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Kendall Green, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-592
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
  Attorney General Melody J. Brown, of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr.,
  of Cheraw, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Kendall
  Green was indicted for and convicted of murder, kidnapping, and grand larceny.Â 
  Green appeals, arguing the trial court erred in refusing to order the removal
  of his restraints during his trial. Â We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR and the
  following authorities:Â  Deck
    v. Missouri, 544 U.S. 622,
  629 (2005) (holding the use of physical restraints visible to
  the jury are prohibited absent a trial court determination, in the exercise of
  its discretion, that they are justified by a state interest specific to a
  particular trial);Â  State v. Tucker, 320 S.C. 206, 209, 464 S.E.2d 105, 107
  (1995) (providing that the trial judge is to balance the
  prejudicial effect of shackling with the considerations of courtroom decorum
  and security; whether a defendant is restrained during trial is within the
  trial judgeâ€™s discretion; and the trial judge is the best equipped to decide the
  extent to which security measures should be adopted to prevent disruption of
  the trial, harm to those in the courtroom, escape of the accused, and
  prevention of other crimes);Â  State
    v. Price, 368 S.C. 494, 500, 629
  S.E.2d 363, 366 (2006) (holding an issue cannot be raised for the first time on
  appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be
  preserved for appellate review);Â  State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 296, 509 S.E.2d 476, 483 (1998) (holding
  where appellant failed to object to jury charge, issue was not preserved for
  consideration on appeal).
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN,
  C.J., HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Sandtonyo
      Lamont Barber, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-593
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, South Carolina Commission
  on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
				
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of
  Columbia; and Solicitor Kevin S. Brackett, of York, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Sandtonyo
  Lamont Barber appeals from
  his convictions for first-degree criminal
  sexual conduct (CSC), kidnapping, and strong armed robbery.Â  Barber argues the
  trial court abused its discretion by allowing a nurse employed by the Rock Hill
  Police Department to provide opinion testimony as to the cause of the victimâ€™s
  injuries when she was merely qualified as an expert in gathering evidence
  through a sexual assault exam.Â  We find this precise issue
  was never raised to the trial court and affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR and the
  following authorities:Â  Wilder Corp.
    v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is
  axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must
  have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for
  appellate review.â€);Â  State v.
    Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 134, 620 S.E.2d 737, 741 (2005) (finding an issue
  not properly preserved for appeal where one ground is raised below and another
  ground is raised on appeal);Â  State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58-59, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005)
  (holding to preserve an issue for review there must be a contemporaneous objection
  that is ruled upon by the trial court with the objection addressed to the trial
  court in a sufficiently specific manner that brings attention to the exact
  error, and if a party fails to properly object, he is procedurally barred from
  raising the issue on appeal).
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN,
  C.J., HUFF, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

				LaNelle C. DuRant, South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Mark Bonner appeals his conviction for
  shoplifting, arguing the trial court erred in proceeding with his trial in absentia.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: State v.
    Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (stating in criminal
  cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by
  the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous); State
    v. Jackson, 288 S.C. 94, 95-96, 341
  S.E.2d 375, 375 (1986) (explaining before a trial in absentia begins, the trial court must make findings of fact regarding whether the
  appellant had received notice of his right to be present and whether the
  appellant had been warned that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a
  failure to attend court).Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â

  370 S.C. 206, 212, 634 S.E.2d 51, 55 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œ[W]hen an appellant

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				J. Doe, Appellant,
				v.
				Richard L.
      Duncan, Meredith Bond, Sidney Gilreath and Gilreath & Associates, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-596
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Cynthia E. Collie, of Sullivans Island, for Appellant.
				Curtis W. Dowling, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: J.
  Doe appeals the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of her causes of action pursuant to
  Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:
1.  As to whether the trial court erred in its interpretation and application of
  Rule 12(b)(8), SCRCP, in dismissing her causes of action:Â  Â Â Â Green By & Through Green v.
    Lewis Truck Lines, Inc., 314 S.C. 303, 304, 443 S.E.2d 906, 907 (1994)
  (explaining that in interpreting the language of a court rule, we apply the same rules
  of construction used in interpreting
  statutes); Corbett v. City of Myrtle Beach, 336 S.C. 601, 610,
  521 S.E.2d 276, 281 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding dismissal pursuant to Rule
  12(b)(8), SCRCP, appropriate where claim involved the same parties and were
  based upon the same facts and circumstances); Cox v. Woodmen of World Ins.
    Co., 347 S.C. 460, 469-70, 556 S.E.2d 397, 402 (Ct. App. 2001)
  (explaining the Â trial court properly denied a motion to dismiss pursuant to
  Rule 12(b)(8) where a class action in an Alabama court involving the same
  parties and the same or substantially the same issues was decertified).Â Â  
2.  As
  to whether the trial court failed to consider a stay as an alternative to
  dismissal:Â  State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003)
  (stating a party may not argue one ground at trial and an alternate ground on
  appeal).Â  
3.  As to
  whether the trial court erred in failing to apply Tennessee law and failed to
  reverse pursuant to Rule 61, SCRCP: In re Care and Treatment of McCracken,
  346 S.C. 87, 92, 551 S.E.2d 235, 238 (2001) (holding an issue is deemed
  abandoned and will not be considered on appeal if the argument is raised in a
  brief but not supported by authority).Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ.,
  concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				James Wright, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-597
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008Â Â Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J.
  Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: James Wright appeals his conviction and sentence for
  murder, arguing the trial court erred by refusing to charge the jury on
  involuntary manslaughter.Â  After a
  thorough review of the record, counselâ€™s brief, and Wrightâ€™s pro se brief
  pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v.
    Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss[1] Wrightâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
APPEAL
  DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Causey v. SC Budget and Control Board

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Lisa Kay Causey, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Budget and Control Board, South Carolina Retirement Systems, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From the Administrative Law Court
Â Marvin F. Kittrell, Administrative Law
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-598
Submitted October 1, 2008 â€“ Filed October
  17, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Lisa
  Kay Causey, pro se, for Appellant.
				Justin R. Werner and David K. Avant, of Columbia, Â for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Lisa K. Causey appeals the denial of her claim for
  disability retirement, arguing the Administrative Law Court (ALC) erred (1) in
  finding the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the record
  supported denial, (2) in assigning weight to expert testimony, and (3) in
  excluding her medical literature as inadmissible hearsay.Â  Causey further
  argues her inability to secure counsel placed her at an unconstitutional
  disadvantage.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities.Â  
1.  As
  to the question whether the ALC erred in finding the reliable, probative, and
  substantial evidence on the record supported denial:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(B) (Supp. 2007) (providing a
  party who has exhausted administrative remedies and obtained a final agency
  determination from an executive-branch agency may seek a contested case hearing
  from the ALC); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1540 (Supp. 2007) (rendering a member
  eligible for disability retirement benefits when South Carolina Retirement
  Systems, â€œafter a medical examination of the member, certifies that the member
  is mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty,
  that the incapacity is likely to be permanent, and that the member should be
  retired.â€); Terry v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 377 S.C.
  569, 573, 660 S.E.2d 291, 293 (Ct. App. 2008) (â€œIn administrative law cases,
  the ALC serves as the fact-finder and is not restricted by the findings of the
  administrative agency.â€).Â Â  
2.  As
  to whether the ALC erred in assigning weight to expert testimony: Â In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be
  raised for the first time on appeal. Â In order to preserve an issue for appeal,
  it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  Â Â 
3.  As
  to whether the ALC erred in excluding Causeyâ€™s medical literature as
  inadmissible hearsay:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-330(1) (2005) (requiring the ALC to exclude â€œ[i]rrelevant, immaterial or
  unduly repetitious evidenceâ€ from contested case hearings and otherwise follow
  the South Carolina Rules of Evidence applicable in civil cases in the court of
  common pleas); Rule 801(c), SCRE (â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one
  made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in
  evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€); Rule 803(18), SCRE (excluding
  learned treatises from introduction as exhibits but providing a limited
  exception for their admissibility when read into evidence during examination of
  an expert witness).Â  
4.  As
  to whether Causeyâ€™s inability to secure counsel placed her at an unconstitutional
  disadvantage:Â  DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361
  S.C. 416, 424-25, 604 S.E.2d 704, 709 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding constitutional
  issues not raised to and ruled on by a lower court are not preserved for
  appellate review).Â  
5.  As
  to all remaining issues:Â  In re
    Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602
  S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on
  appeal. Â In order to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial court.â€); DuRant v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control,
  361 S.C. 416, 424-25, 604 S.E.2d 704, 709 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding
  constitutional issues not raised to and ruled on by a lower court are not
  preserved for appellate review).Â  
AFFIRMED. 
SHORT,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Johnson v. Spartanburg County School District 7
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Patricia
          Johnson, as Guardian Ad Litem for Child, a minor, Respondent,
        v.
        Spartanburg County School District 7, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-600
  Heard October 21, 2008 â€“ Filed October 27,
2008

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND
REMANDED


  
    
      
        Kenneth E. Darr, Jr., and Carlos C. Johnson, both of Spartanburg, for Appellant.Â  
        Gary W. Poliakoff, of Â Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Spartanburg County School District 7 (the School District) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of Patricia Johnsonâ€™s motion for a
  temporary injunction and the relief sought in her equitable bill of discovery.Â 
  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s order granting the temporary injunction, reverse
  the circuit courtâ€™s order granting the relief requested in Johnsonâ€™s equitable
  bill of discovery, and remand the matter for a full hearing on the merits.Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
FACTS
Johnson
  is the guardian ad litem for Child,[1] a minor who was allegedly the victim of a sexual assault on a school bus in
  September 2006.Â  On April 16, 2007, Johnson filed a summons and complaint
  seeking an equitable bill of discovery and a temporary injunction.Â  Johnson
  asked the circuit court to order the School District to maintain, preserve, and
  produce certain items and information relating to the incident and to refrain
  from moving, removing, or modifying any such items and information.Â  Johnson
  contended the School District had conducted an investigation, including taking
  witness statements and gathering other information, following the incident.Â 
  Johnson, therefore, wanted any information or evidence the School District had
  gathered to be preserved so she could determine whether any potential civil
  causes of action existed, identify all potential defendants, and potentially
  proceed with any civil matters related to the incident.Â  The summons stated the
  School District had thirty days to file its answer.Â  
On
  April 19, 2007, the circuit court issued an Order and Rule to Show Cause, directing
  the School District to appear on May 9, 2007, and show cause as to why the
  relief requested should not be granted.Â  The circuit court stated:Â Â Â  

  [I]t
    would be prudent and proper to [o]rder [the School District] to maintain the
    evidence referenced in [Johnsonâ€™s] [c]omplaint ([f]or [e]quitable [b]ill [of]
    [d]iscovery), in a safe place and to refrain and restrain from moving it,
    removing it and/or making any modifications to this evidence, along with any
    other items or materials that might potentially be considered as evidence in
    any possible civil litigation, until the hearing in this matter . . . .

The
  School District appeared at the hearing but argued the circuit court lacked
  personal jurisdiction to rule in the matter because the thirty days in which
  the School District could respond to either the summons and complaint or the
  Rule to Show Cause had yet to expire.Â  The circuit court disagreed with the School Districtâ€™s argument and proceeded with the hearing.[2]Â Â Â  
At
  the close of the hearing, the circuit court stated it would allow Johnson to
  proceed with discovery.Â  The circuit court finalized this decision by order on
  July 17, 2007.Â  This order specified the discovery Johnson could move
  forward with and granted Johnsonâ€™s request for an injunction.Â  Specifically,
  the circuit court ordered the School District to preserve and maintain the
  evidence referenced in Johnsonâ€™s complaint for equitable bill of discovery,
  along with any other items or materials that might be potentially considered as
  evidence in the possible civil litigation.Â  The circuit court acknowledged
  Johnson was requesting evidence before any suit had been filed and that Johnson
  was not asking the circuit court to bind any defendant to any judgment.Â  The
  circuit court concluded the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure and
  relevant case law provided for reasonable pre-suit discovery and for
  preservation of evidence.Â  The circuit court noted, if a party were to sue
  without grounds, that party could face court-imposed penalties as well as
  liability for a groundless action.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On
  July 20, 2007, the School District filed a Motion to Reconsider and Amend,
  which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œActions
  for injunctive relief are equitable in nature.â€Â  Shaw v. Coleman, 373
  S.C. 485, 492, 645 S.E.2d 252, 256 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  When reviewing actions in
  equity, this Court may â€œcorrect errors of law and may find facts in accordance
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Blackmon v. Weaver,
  366 S.C. 245, 249, 621 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2005).Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The School District argues the circuit court erroneously granted Johnsonâ€™s request for a
  temporary injunction because she failed to demonstrate two of the requirements
  for a temporary injunction: (1) the likelihood of success on the merits and (2)
  an inadequate remedy at law.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The
  granting of a temporary injunction rests in the discretion of the trial court.Â  Powell v. Immanuel Baptist Church, 261 S.C. 219, 221, 199 S.E.2d 60, 61
  (1973).Â  The sole purpose for granting a temporary injunction is to preserve
  status quo in order to avoid possible irreparable injury to a party.Â  Id.Â  To establish a cause of action for a temporary injunction, a party must
  demonstrate (1) irreparable harm will be suffered if the injunction is not
  granted, (2) success on the merits is likely, and (3) the remedy at law is
  inadequate.Â  Peek v. Spartanburg Regâ€™l Healthcare Sys., 367 S.C. 450,
  454-55, 626 S.E.2d 34, 36 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
At
  the hearing, Johnson argued she would likely succeed on the merits of the case
  because the South Carolina Supreme Court has stated an equitable bill of
  discovery is an independent civil action used to proceed with the discovery
  process when the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provide no other
  mechanism for doing so.Â  Wofford v. Ethyl Corp., 316 S.C. 75, 77, 447
  S.E.2d 187, 189 (1994).Â  Further, Johnson argued if the evidence gathered for
  this case was not preserved, she would suffer immediate and irreparable injury
  by not being able to examine the evidence or pursue a valid civil action,
  leaving her with no legal remedy.Â  We find there to be a sufficient showing to
  support the circuit courtâ€™s decision to grant the temporary injunction and,
  consequently, no abuse of discretion.Â  
The School District also argues the circuit court erroneously determined the merits of the case
  at the hearing on May 9, 2007, because the Rule to Show Cause did not contain
  the essential elements of a summons, and thus, the circuit court did not have
  proper personal jurisdiction to grant the relief requested by Johnson.Â  While
  we find the circuit court had personal jurisdiction to hear the matter because
  the motion for a temporary injunction was before it, we agree that the circuit
  court erroneously decided the merits of the case.
Although
  a court may consider the merits of a case to the extent necessary to determine
  whether a temporary injunction should be issued, it is improper for a court to
  make a final determination on the merits of a case at the hearing for a
  temporary injunction.Â  Roberts v. Union County Bd. of Sch. Trs., 284
  S.C. 299, 301, 326 S.E.2d 163, 164 (Ct. App. 1985); see also Helsel
    v. City of N. Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 32, 413 S.E.2d 824, 826 (1992) (â€œWhen
  a court is requested to issue a temporary injunction it may consider the merits
  of a case to the extent necessary to determine whether a temporary injunction
  is appropriate.â€).Â  Â Â Â Â 
In
  the current case, the circuit court scheduled a hearing on May 9, 2007,
  ordering the School District to appear and show cause as to why Johnsonâ€™s
  request for temporary relief should not be granted pending a hearing on the
  merits.Â  At the hearing, the circuit court granted Johnsonâ€™s motion for a temporary
  injunction and allowed her to proceed with discovery.Â  By allowing discovery to
  move forward, the circuit court granted Johnson the relief requested in her equitable
  bill of discovery and, thus, decided the merits of the case.Â  As stated, it is
  improper for a court to make a final determination on the merits of a case upon
  a hearing to determine whether a party is entitled to a temporary injunction,
  and therefore, the circuit court erred in deciding whether Johnson was entitled
  to the relief requested in her equitable bill of discovery.Â  See Roberts,
  284 S.C. at 301, 326 S.E.2d at 164 (finding the circuit court should not decide
  the merits of a case at a hearing regarding entitlement to a temporary
  injunction).Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is reversed and the matter
  is remanded for a full hearing on the merits.Â  
In
  light of our decision on these issues, we need not address the remaining
  arguments on appeal.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown,
    Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (finding when a
  decision of one issue is dispositive, it is not necessary to decide remaining
  issues on appeal).Â  
CONCLUSION
For the
  foregoing reasons, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON,
WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 


[1] Â The name of the minor child has been changed to
protect the minor childâ€™s identity.Â  
[2] On May 21, 2007, the School District filed its answer
to Johnsonâ€™s summons and complaint.Â Â Â

PER CURIAM:Â
